reviewText: Classic War CollectionThese four movies each tell about one branch of the US military. They are all good, but there are other movies out there that could be better. Audie Murphy's film alone is worth buying and viewing."Wake Island" (1942) is about the defense of Wake Island by the Marines against a Japanese invasion. It is based on an historical event. The screen play was written by W. R. Burnett. [I think "The Sands of Iwo Jima" is the best historical drama of the Marine Corps.]"To Hell and Back" (1955) is a drama about the life and exploits of Audie Murphy, the most decorated soldier of World War II. It was based on Murphy's book, which has more details. "A Walk in the Sun" (1945) written by Harry Brown is about the average soldier, and there were many others."Battle Hymn" (1957) is a drama about the Air Force in Korea. The Air Force was part of the Army in WW II. "Eight O'Clock High" is about strategic bombing and air war in WW II Europe."Gray Lady Down" (1978) is a drama about Navy submariners (a submarine in trouble). Any of the movies about the Battle of the Atlantic or the War in the Pacific would probably be better.

reviewText: The four movie set was very dated, but one has to keep in mind these were primarily propaganda films, either produced during the second world war or shortly after while the world was still "celebrating its heroes and honorable dead".The quality varied substantially, To Hell and Back was certainly the best of the group in that respect.Each movie told a worthwhile story from the period and each honoured different aspects of the war covering most theatres.If you enjoy this period, you will watch these knowing their limitations and original target audience and appreciate them for what they are.Children might be bored, but it will certainly help their education of a very important period that's only now slipping from living memory.At the very modest price that Amazon is requiring, certainly a good buy, and mostly what gets the collection 4 stars, otherwise it's a 3* collection.Otherwise I'd go as follows, averaging accross the movies.Sets - 3*Acting - 3*Storyboards - 3*Effects - 2*Historical accuracy - 3*Entertainment value - 3*
summary: B+ grade wartime movies but still enjoyable

reviewText: -----------------------------------------------------"Four-Movie Marathon: Classic War Collection"(Universal Studios, 2011)-----------------------------------------------------A two-disc, four-movie collection of top-quality Grade-B war movies, where war is heck and the guys are all swell. This is the kind of stuff they used to show on afternoon TV back when I was a kid, full of corny dialog and American ideals. The colelction includes:"Wake Island" (1942)A real-deal wartime propaganda film, released in 1942, just months after Pearl Harbor and the defeat of a USMC garrison on Wake Island, just west of Hawaii. In December, 1941 the Marines held the atoll for two weeks against a ferocious Japanese assault, a story that is told here in classic idealized Hollywood style: the Americans are regular guys and big lugs who love pretty dames and puppy dogs and can gun down enemy soldiers by the truckload. The movie ends abruptly, on a sad note, with all the heroes being overrun by Japanese soldiers and killed within minutes. (In real life, most of the Marines were captured as POWs...) Hollywood does its best to put a positive spin on things, playing the Marines up as martyrs and exhorting the nation to keep fighting. Lots of aerial dogfight scenes, blown-up model ships and plenty of explosions on the ground. An oldie and a goodie."To Hell and Back" (1955)The Audie Murphy story, told with WWII hero Murphy himself starring in the lead. This Technicolor film is a little clunky; an attempt to revive American's enthusiasm for military readiness in the wake of the demoralizing, unpopular Korean War. Murphy makes the transition from a nervous, green farmboy to a fearless fighting machine."Battle Hymn" (1957)Rock Hudson stars in this colorful, sentimental exercise in Korean War revisionism, in which a retired pilot re-enlists to fight the Reds. The war was very unpopular at the time, and only later became shown as the same kind of "old school" heroic war as WWII."Gray Lady Down" (1978)David Carradine, Charleton Heston and Stacy Keach star in this late-date submarine film - seems a little out of place with the other three, older-vintage films, but still kinda fun.
summary: Great bargain-priced collection of classic Hollywood war films

reviewText: Four great war pictures. "Wake Island" was nominated for the Oscar for Best Picture in 1942. "To Hell and Back" is the true story of Audie L. Murphy, who was the most decorated American hero of World War II. He plays himself in this film! I LOVE this film. To me he is the best example of the American spirit, bravery and patriotism. He deserved every medal he received and still deserves our respect and admiration for his bravery. When you sing the National Anthem and you say "the home of the brave" you should think of Audie L. Murphy! God Rest In Peace Mr. Murphy!!! The other two pictures are also good films.

reviewText: The only complaint I have about this collection is that Gray Lady Down isn't really a war movie. It's more of a rescue movie, where the sub is stuck under water, and people try to rescue them. It doesn't take place in wartime, and no guns are fired. The other three movies are okay. The Rock Hudson movie is a Korean War movie. And I think Wake Island was filmed before even WWII ended, so it's a movie about a war that was still being fought when filmed, but I don't know if any real war action was included. Hell And Back stars a real-life soldier playing himself as the title role, at least that's what it's introduced as and I assume they are honest.

reviewText: "To Hell and Back" is Audie Murphy's true story.  After being turned down by the marines, then the navy, Audie's sister helped forge a birth certificate and Audie got into the army.  He was a born leader though he himself didn't think so.  During WWII he won every medal our military has, plus medals from France and Belgium."Battle Hymn" is the story of a man who wrestled with his conscience, overcame his doubts, and helped save a large group of orphans in battle weary Korea.  A very, very good story."Grey Lady Down" is the story of an inventor who has a sort of minisub.  With it, he saved many lives.  In fact, he gave his own life to save others.  A good film starring david Carradine as the inventor.
summary: Very good true stories of war.

reviewText: I got this disk because I really wanted Wake Island and To Hell and Back.  Battle Hymn and Gray Lady Down were just ideal bargains added to the price of the two movies I really wanted.  Wake Island, though a somewhat fictionalized telling of the story turns out to be very good in depicting what happened on the island up to a point.  That point being when the last message came in from the island.  Except for the ending, the battle for the island is fairly accurate and well worth watching.  To Hell and Back is a greatly down played telling of Audey Murphy's story during the war and well worth watching.  Battle Hymn is a different view of the forgotten Korean War that I've only seen twice but come to enjoy.  And though I wouldn't have necessarily bought Gray Lady Down, it is well worth having in this set and good for watching as well.

Both "To Hell and Back" , and "Gray Lady Down" are also outstanding. I did spend a year at Camp Kaiser, with the 2nd Div. in later years, after switching to the Army, and found the populace to be both industrious, vary intelligent, and ambitious.

reviewText: The 2DVD collection of 4 stories.. Classic War collection was very good. Just wished it would of been on 4 individual DVDs.Wake Island was a good B/W WW11 movie about US marines holding Wake Island for days before every man is killed by overwhelming land attacking forces, enemy plane attack, and being pounded by Japanese Naval forces. True heroism. The Japanese must take Wake island ( a small air strip) in the middle of the Pacific Ocean) as not to leave the Americans a base to launch planes etc. The film was basically a true account by the military. A 4 star general stars the story about the heroism of those who defended Wake Island. 4 starsTo Hell and Back is about the true story of Audie Murphy. We see him as a young boy shooting for food, and later the Japanese attack Pearl Harbor. The Navy. Marines, and Paratroopers reject him as he is too young and kind of frail. The Army accepts him. We see him going up in rank from private to eventually 1st Lieutenant via battlefield commission. He becomes the most decorated American soldier in WW2. Lots of medals including the Medal of Honor. Lots of battlefield action. Great scene of him finding a French woman and their love for each other.Battle Hymn is about a WW2 pilot who mistakenly bombs a orphanage and kills lots of children. He gets out of the military and becomes a minister but is not too good at that. He rejoins the military and is in charge of a training compound training Rock Marine pilots. There is some battle action. The now Colonel and a Korean woman save 400 plus orphaned children. She throws herself on a child to save her from strafing. Later a orphanage is erected dedicated to the Korean woman by the Colonial. Great move with emotional scenes. 5 starsGray Lady Down is about a nuclear sub Neptune hit by a Norwegian ship and sunk. The US Navy uses rescue vehicles to rescue some of the men. Story, lots of action. 5 stars.Total 4 1/2 stars for this great DVD collection.
summary: 3 Great WW11 movies and Rescue of a sub crew trapped

reviewText: I got this collection because I wanted Grey Lady Down, a submarine suspense story with Charlton Heston, David Caradine and Stacey Keach. Wake Island is a classic and can be found singly if desired, but adds to the value of this DVD- several old stars are featured like Brian Donlevy, MacDonald Carey, Robert Preston and William Bendix (and even a doggie subplot). To Hell and Back features Audie Murphy, the most decorated man of the time, at a very young age. I appreciate what he did but this story telling leaves a lot to be desired. Battle Hymn has Rock Hudson as an Air Force commander in a faith crisis. All the films are clear prints with reliable sound quality. All have English Subtitles available for the hearing impaired.
Title: N/A
